arm_group.description: TENS intervention consisted of continuous flow, symmetrical and rectangular TENS biphasic pulses. The frequency ofstimulation was 80 Hz and the pulse duration was 150 μs, with the intensity in  adjusted to the point of muscle contraction.
The frequency of stimulation was 80 Hz and the pulse duration was 150 μs,  equipment did not provide stimulation current.

brief_summary.textblock:
This study will evaluate the applications of ganglionar electrical stimulation in patients
      with Chagas Disease and Ischemic Heart Failure patients.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Ganglionar Electrical Stimulation on Central Arterial Pressure

detailed_description.textblock:
A Crossover Randomized Controlled Study will be developed with 3 groups: Healthy Older,
      Ischemic Heart Failure and Chagas Disease. This individuals will be randomized in two
      groups: TENS and placebo (same stimulus without electrical output) with 48 hrs between the
      interventions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Ischemic and Chagas disease previously diagnosticated

          -  Age above 40 years old

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  No vascular disease

          -  No recent surgery

          -  No recent infections

intervention.description: Adhesive electrodes (MultiStick®, USA) were placed on each side, about 3 cm to the right and left of midline vertebral process, at C7 (Channel 1) and T4 (Channel 2).
The frequency of stimulation was 80 Hz and the pulse duration was 150 μs, equipment did not provide stimulation current.

clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Ganglionar Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation on Central Arterial Pressure in Healthy Young Population

overall_official.affiliation: University Federal of Rio Grande do Sul

oversight_info.authority: Brazil: National Committee of Ethics in Research

primary_outcome.description: Applanation tonometry (AT) accurately reflects arterial stiffness method and has demonstrated a strong correlation with ventricular-vascular coupling. Increased arterial stiffness and wave reflection have also been reported in patients with systolic and diastolic HF.
primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of myostimulation protocol, an expected average of 5 weeks

reference.citation: Cipriano G Jr, de Camargo Carvalho AC, Bernardelli GF, Tayar Peres PA. Kinetics of muscle deoxygenation are accelerated at the onset of heavy-intensity exercise in patients with COPD: relationship to central cardiovascular dynamics. J Appl Physiol. 2008 May;104(5):1341-50. Epub 2008 Mar 20.

Vieira PJ, Ribeiro JP, Cipriano G Jr, Umpierre D, Cahalin LP, Moraes RS, Chiappa GR. Effect of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation on muscle metaboreflex in healthy young and older subjects. Eur J Appl Physiol. 2012 Apr;112(4):1327-34. doi: 10.1007/s00421-011-2084-z. Epub 2011 Jul 28.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPX) is a highly reliable and valid approach to assessing aerobic performance. It is a well-accepted assessment technique in the HF population with American and European associations  endorsing its use. CPX is most often performed on a treadmill or cycle ergometer using ramping protocols and the addition of ventilatory expired gas analysis to the standard exercise test enables measurement of oxygen consumption (VO2), carbon dioxide production (VCO2) and minute ventilation (VE) over time. Moreover, CPX provides a host of variables that are  predictive of adverse events in HF patients, including peak VO2, the VE/VCO2 slope and the oxygen uptake efficiency slope (OUES).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of myostimulation protocol, an expected average of 5 weeks

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator), Primary Purpose: Supportive Care
